docs.lead_paragraph: A federal agency has concluded that the Allstate Insurance Company was illegally discriminating against about 650 life insurance agents even as it was negotiating to settle similar charges involving thousands of agents who sell auto and home insurance, several agents and the company disclosed yesterday. In a letter to both sides in the dispute dated May 10, Lynn Bruner, a district director of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, said Allstate had engaged in ''unlawful interference, coercion and intimidation'' against the life insurance agents in 2000 and 2001.

headline.main: Allstate Said To Coerce Life Agents

docs.abstract: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission concludes that Allstate Insurance Co was illegally discriminating against about 650 life insurance agents even as it was negotiating to settle similar charges involving thousands of agents who sell auto and home insurance; EEOC's district director Lynn Bruner, in letter to both sides in dispute, says Allstate engaged in 'unlawful interference, coercion and intimidation' against life insurance agents in 2000 and 2001; commission claims Allstate required agents to convert from being employees with health and pension benefits into independent contractors; Bruner says Allstate has acknowledged telling agents they would not be permitted to work for company unless they agreed in writing not to sue for any kind of employment discrimination; says such action is form of pre-emptive retaliation (M)
docs.snippet: A federal agency has concluded that the Allstate Insurance Company was illegally discriminating against about 650 life insurance agents even as it was negotiating to settle similar charges involving thousands of agents who sell auto and home...

docs.lead_paragraph: He said it was not a campaign kickoff, but Senator Robert G. Torricelli opened his re-election headquarters here with a stump speech that showed he was off and running as he promoted his accomplishments in Congress and ignored the three Republicans who want to be his opponent in November. The senator, a Democrat seeking a second term, said he had chosen New Brunswick because it was the home of Rutgers University, his alma mater, and because he wanted the campaign to be about education.

headline.main: This Isn't a Kickoff Talk, Torricelli Says

docs.lead_paragraph: This town's reputation as ''the sweetest place on earth'' has taken a beating since 2,700 workers went on strike three weeks ago, shutting down two factories that make Hershey's Kisses, Mr. Goodbar and other candies. Hershey's reputation comes not just from chocolate manufacturing but also from the benevolence of the founder of Hershey Chocolate, Milton Hershey. He used company profits to build an orphanage, and instead of laying off workers in the Depression, he put them to work constructing buildings that gave his employees a better life: an arena, a theater and a high school.

headline.main: Resentments as Workers Strike in a Town Built on Chocolate

docs.abstract: Workers at Hershey Foods Corp go on strike, shutting down two candy factories in Hershey, Pa; accuse company and current chief executive, Richard H Lenny, of betraying paternalistic ideals of company's founder, Milton Hershey, citing Lenny's proposal that workers pay more toward health coverage; Lenny's $4.7 million salary last year and stock options that could someday be worth more than $10 million have also stoked employee resentment; photos (M)
docs.snippet: This town's reputation as ''the sweetest place on earth'' has taken a beating since 2,700 workers went on strike three weeks ago, shutting down two factories that make Hershey's Kisses, Mr. Goodbar and other candies.    Hershey's reputation comes not...

docs.lead_paragraph: After New York State's legislators adopted their $90 billion budget this week, one leader lovingly called it a ''miracle.'' If a miracle is something that may be too good to be true, then he's right. This budget is designed to do one thing well -- re-elect incumbents this fall. It is full of apparent good news, especially for New York City, while under the press releases are signs of financial trouble. To fill a big and growing revenue gap, the budget uses up most of the state's savings and reserves, $3.1 billion, and borrows an additional $900 million. Gov. George Pataki's earlier argument that New York's calamities justified exemptions from normal budget-making rules seemed to make sense. But now there is a growing concern that this final plan was entirely driven by the election calendar.
docs.abstract: Editorial says $90 billion budget approved by New York State legislators is filled with election-year largess and does not provide taxes to pay for it; deplores fact that to fill big and growing gap, budget uses up most of state's savings and reserves, $3.1 billion, and borrows $900 million

docs.lead_paragraph: Pasquale Di Tillio says his pizzeria on Cortlandt Street, half a block from the World Trade Center site, is doing about a third of the business it did before the terrorist attack eight months ago. Jim Boudouvas, a Fulton Street florist whose shop is little more than a block from the site, says his business is down about 40 percent from pre-Sept. 11 levels.

headline.main: Lower Manhattan Retailers Still Suffer Without Foot Traffic

docs.abstract: Many small retail, food and service businesses in Lower Manhattan that rely on local walk-in trade or telephone orders are struggling in aftermath of Sept 11 terrorist attack on World Trade Center; owners of these businesses listen to talk of redeveloment of devastated site and rejuvenation of area, and wonder if they will be around to benefit from any recovery; exactly how many distressed small retailers there are in area is uncertain; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Federally mediated contract talks between Hershey Foods and the union representing 3,000 striking workers broke down yesterday over health care benefits. Two Hershey candy plants have been shut as a result of the strike, which began April 26. The workers' contract expired Nov. 4. The company's latest proposal met the union's request for wage increases and provided for retroactive compensation in the form of a signing bonus. But the proposal asked that employees share the cost of health care, though at a lower level than previously suggested. Union officials said nearly 87 percent of the workers had voted against higher co-payments.

headline.main: LABOR TALKS AT HERSHEY STALL OVER HEALTH BENEFITS

docs.abstract: Federally mediated contract talks between Hershey Foods and union representing 3,000 striking workers break down over health care benefits; two Hershey candy plants have been shut as result of strike, which began April 26 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Legislature and the governor acted today to require health insurance plans to cover most infertility treatments, bringing an abrupt, surprising end to three years of wrangling. The mandate was inserted into one of the bills that make up the state budget after overnight negotiations involving the Senate, the Assembly and Gov. George E. Pataki. The Legislature passed the bills today, and the governor's office said he would sign them.

headline.main: State Will Require Coverage Of Treatment for Infertility

docs.abstract: New York State legislature and Gov Pataki act to require health insurance plans to cover most infertility treatments, bringing abrupt, surprising end to three years of wrangling (M)
docs.snippet: The Legislature and the governor acted today to require health insurance plans to cover most infertility treatments, bringing an abrupt, surprising end to three years of wrangling.    The mandate was inserted into one of the bills that make up the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Operating in closed meetings, state lawmakers today began absorbing details of the gargantuan budget bills negotiated by their leaders. The legislators, juggling dozens of dollar figures largely in their heads, were to begin voting on the bills Thursday morning. Late tonight, the administration released some details of the $89.6 billion plan that has been hammered out in secret meetings between the legislative leaders and the governor over the last two weeks. The talks have not included rank-and-file legislators, who tonight still had yet to be given details on paper. Nor had they seen the bills, although the leaders had briefed them extensively.

headline.main: A Race to Vote On a Budget In Albany

docs.abstract: New York legislators will tackle $89.6 billion budget plan that has been hammered out in secret meetings by Gov George Pataki, Speaker Sheldon Silver and Sen Joseph Bruno over last two weeks; spending will rise about 6 percent; budget depends heavily on spending about $1.2 billion of state's savings, borrowing hundreds of millions and using about $1 billion in other one-time revenues, allowing state to avert deep cuts in services; some lawmakers are concerned about borrowing and using one-shot revenues (M)
docs.snippet: Operating in closed meetings, state lawmakers today began absorbing details of the gargantuan budget bills negotiated by their leaders. The legislators, juggling dozens of dollar figures largely in their heads, were to begin voting on the bills...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Arafat Promises Reform; Israel Is Skeptical Yasir Arafat responded to growing Palestinian and international pressure for reform by acknowledging mistakes and promising changes to his administration and new elections. The Palestinian leader spoke a day after Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel demanded Palestinian reform as a condition for negotiations. A1 A senior Israeli military official said there was no point in America's undertaking a mission to rebuild the Palestinian security force while Mr. Arafat was in charge and that Israel needed to retain responsibility for security in the occupied territories. A12

docs.lead_paragraph: With thousands of New Jersey doctors struggling to find insurance against medical malpractice lawsuits, at least four groups are trying to start new companies to provide coverage. But even if the new ventures are successful, they will only partly address a growing nationwide problem that has arrived with full force in New Jersey, and is heading for New York and Connecticut.

headline.main: Patching Together Help as Doctors' Insurance Unravels

docs.abstract: Doctors in New Jersey struggle to find affordable medical malpractice insurance as prices there, and throughout metropolitan area, rise sharply; three companies that insured about half state's estimated 24,000 doctors have either collapsed or withdrawn from malpractice coverage in New Jersey; some doctors are appealing to lawmakers for help in limiting costs, contending that rising jury awards and settlements make it impossible for insurance companies to survive (M)
